examples.en: In my case, that worked out well for me.
examples.ja: 私の場合は、それでうまくいきました。

examples.en: What should I do in this situation?
examples.ja: この場合は、どうすればいいですか？

examples.en: I think in that case, it's better to call a professional.
examples.ja: その場合はプロを呼んだ方がいいと思う。

meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>location</kanji> <kanji>suit</kanji>s a situation the best? That always depends on the <vocabulary>case</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>circumstance</vocabulary>. You can't know the suitability of the location until you have all the facts about the circumstances.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You didn't learn these readings with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

There are few <vocabulary>case</vocabulary>s where you want to <reading>baa</reading> (ば) while making <reading>eye</reading>s (あい) at someone. In the <vocabulary>circumstance</vocabulary> of a sheep looking for love, it may be acceptable, but in any other <vocabulary>situation</vocabulary> it's probably not appropriate behavior.

examples.en: It's not good to keep people waiting.
examples.ja: 人を待たせるのは良くないよ。

examples.en: How much longer are you going to make me wait?
examples.ja: 一体いつまで待たせるつもりですか？

examples.en: Sorry for making you wait so long. I had to wait for the bus for such a long time.
examples.ja: お待たせしてすみません。いや〜バスにえらく長いこと待たされましてね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the たせ as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this. That'll help you remember that this means <vocabulary>to make someone wait</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to keep someone waiting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading from 待つ, congrats!

examples.en: Koichi and I are companions from the same company.
examples.ja: コウイチとは同じ会社の仲間です。

examples.en: I got this shirt from my golf buddy.
examples.ja: このシャツはゴルフ仲間にもらったんだ。

examples.en: My group of friends and I relaxed after a hard day at school.
examples.ja: 学校での厳しい一日を終えて、仲間たちとリラックスをした。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>relationship</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is very short between you and your <vocabulary>comrade</vocabulary>s. You are <vocabulary>companion</vocabulary>s who have been through thick and thin together, so there's no distance between you.

仲間 is one of those very Japanese words that's hard to translate directly into English. It's a warm word that refers to people you share something with, like work, hobbies, goals, or even struggles. 仲間 aren't necessarily friends in the "get a coffee and chat" sense, but they're people with whom you've built a strong and special bond based on a shared experience or sense of purpose.
reading_mnemonic:
You know the readings for both of these kanji. 仲 uses the same reading as always, and 間 uses the ま reading, which you learned with 間もなく. Since 間 has a few different readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember to use the ま one:

Think through all your companions in your life. Imagine one of them is your <reading>Ma</reading> (ま). She's on your pirate crew, and a pretty awesome pirate.

examples.en: I like kimono.
examples.ja: 私は着物が好きです。

examples.en: Your kimono is lovely.
examples.ja: ステキなお着物ですね。

examples.en: I bought a kimono at the department store.
examples.ja: デパートで着物を買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>thing</kanji>s you <kanji>wear</kanji> are your <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>. Oh, and Japanese clothes count too. We're talking <vocabulary>kimono</vocabulary>s. Way back when, these could just be called <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary> because it's all people really wore, but nowadays we know they're specific to the stereotypical kimono you think of when you think "Japan."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit strange using kun'yomi readings. Luckily, we taught you these already, so go put on that kimono of yours and relax at the 温泉 for a bit.

examples.en: The underwear section is over there.
examples.ja: 下着売り場はあちらです。

examples.en: Lately, I often order underwear online.
examples.ja: 最近は、私は下着はネットで注文することが多いです。

examples.en: Oh, is that your special underwear? Looks cool!
examples.ja: おおっ、それって勝負下着？かっこいいね！

meaning_mnemonic: The things you <kanji>wear</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> your other clothes. That is your <vocabulary>underwear</vocabulary>. You do wear underwear, right?
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

examples.en: Did you remember to bring your swimsuit?
examples.ja: 水着、ちゃんと持ってきた？

examples.en: That swimsuit is cute!
examples.ja: あの水着、かわいい！

examples.en: Oh, look. The swimsuits are on sale.
examples.ja: あ、見て。水着がセール中だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>wear</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swimsuit</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>bathing suit</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>swimwear</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with the vocab word 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

examples.en: Do you think I'll make it if I leave now?
examples.ja: 今から出て、間に合うと思う？

examples.en: If we get in a taxi right now, we might still make it on time.
examples.ja: 今すぐタクシーに乗れば、まだ間に合うかもしれません。

examples.en: Sorry! Eating ramen took longer than I thought, and I'm not going to make it to the meeting on time.
examples.ja: ごめん！ラーメン食べるのに思ったより時間がかかって、待ち合わせに間に合いそうにない。

meaning_mnemonic: There is an <kanji>interval</kanji> (of time) that you need "to suit" (合う). To suit that interval, you need to be there before the time in question. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be in time for</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make it on time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on time for</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading for 間 when you learned 間もなく. And the reading for 合う is just that of the word 合う. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

examples.en: Do you know each other?
examples.ja: お知り合いですか？

examples.en: Since I know that person, I'll ask them about it.
examples.ja: 知り合いだから、ちょっと聞いてみるよ。

examples.en: I absolutely don't want it to be known that I'm acquainted with them.
examples.ja: アイツと知り合いだとはゼッタイにバレたくない。

meaning_mnemonic: You've probably seen the words 知る and 合う by now. This is someone you "know" because you have "come together" before, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them well, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an <vocabulary>acquaintance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are that of 知る and 合う. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.

examples.en: I'm currently waiting alone. I wonder if everyone will come?
examples.ja: 今、待ちぼうけ中だよ。 みんな来るのかな？

examples.en: Without realizing I'd been deceived, I ended up waiting alone at a deserted station for three hours.
examples.ja: ダマされてたことに気づかず、さびれた駅で三時間も待ちぼうけをしていました。

examples.en: Make sure to let Misaki know that tomorrow's meeting has been canceled so she doesn't feel stood up, okay?
examples.ja: 待ちぼうけを食らったと思わないように、明日のミーティングが中止になったこと、ミサキさんにもちゃんと教えといてあげてね？

meaning_mnemonic: With <vocabulary>待ち</vocabulary> you know you're waiting, but what's a <vocabulary>ぼうけ</vocabulary>? Turns out it's the long version of ボケ which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were <vocabulary>stood up</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 待ち comes right from 待つ. You know the drill by now.

examples.en: It is thanks to all of you that I am here now.
examples.ja: 私が今ここにいるのは、皆様のおかげです。

examples.en: Everybody, please stand up.
examples.ja: 皆様、ご起立ください。

examples.en: We need everyone's help to make this project a success!
examples.ja: このプロジェクトを成功させるには、皆様のお力が必要なんです！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Everyone</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>). This is just a polite way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary> (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).
reading_mnemonic: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.

meanings: If You Would Be So Kind

examples.en: Two adult tickets, please.
examples.ja: 大人のチケットを二枚、お願いします。

examples.en: Please do something about it. Can't you make it work somehow?
examples.ja: そこをなんとか、お願いします。どうにかなりませんか？

examples.en: Please God! I want to be fluent in Japanese.
examples.ja: 神様、お願いします！日本語が上手くなりたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the <kanji>request</kanji> kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (<vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>) and you're asking very nicely too (<vocabulary>please</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: You ask for help by saying <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so <reading>neg</reading>ligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

examples.en: Oh, I forget, how do I get to the main building?
examples.ja: あれ、本館にはどうやって行けばいいんだっけ？

examples.en: Then, let's meet at the main entrance at nine o'clock!
examples.ja: じゃあ、本館の入り口に九時で！

examples.en: Restrooms are located on the first floor of the main building.
examples.ja: トイレは本館の１Fにあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
One of the meanings of 本 is <kanji>main</kanji> (which is what we're using here). The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main building</vocabulary>.

Sometimes 本館 can also mean <vocabulary>this building</vocabulary>, as in the one you're in. I guess whatever building you're in sort of becomes the main one to you, right?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

For you advanced learners out there, you might want to know that saying that this word like Kyoko gets you the <vocabulary>main building</vocabulary> meaning, while saying it like Kenichi gets you the <vocabulary>this building</vocabulary> meaning! Isn't pitch accent fun? But you'll probably never have to worry about this — context clues will be enough to tell you which meaning is being used.

examples.en: Japanese erasers have incredibly high quality.
examples.ja: 日本の消しゴムはクオリティがすごく高い。

examples.en: Hey, do you have an eraser?
examples.ja: ねえ、消しゴム持ってる？

examples.en: I got dumped when I gave her eraser-shaped earrings as a Christmas present.
examples.ja: クリスマスに、彼女に消しゴムの形のイヤリングをプレゼントしたら、フラれました。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word 消す, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ゴム. ゴム is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an <vocabulary>eraser</vocabulary> that extinguishes pencil markings.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 消す, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

examples.en: I'm sorry, I didn't mean any harm.
examples.ja: ごめんなさい、悪気はなかったんです。

examples.en: I know you didn't mean any harm, but what you just said was too harsh.
examples.ja: 悪気がないのは分かってるけど、今のはヒドすぎるよ。

examples.en: The problem is that when there's no ill intent, it's more insidious. They're doing it naturally, so there's nothing that can be done about it.
examples.ja: 悪気がない方がタチが悪いよ。ナチュラルにやってるんだから、どうしようもないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone with <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is someone who has <vocabulary>evil intent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>malice</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>ill will</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much 悪気.
reading_mnemonic: The reading itself has a lot of 悪気 with all the exceptions it has. The 悪 part is read like 悪い. Then, 気 is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

examples.en: Do you go mountain climbing, Mr. Yamada?
examples.ja: 山田さんって、山登りするんですか？

examples.en: The other day, I went mountain climbing with a friend.
examples.ja: 先日、友人と山登りに行ってきました。

examples.en: You shouldn't underestimate mountain climbing, but eating soft serve ice cream after a climb is the best.
examples.ja: 山登りをなめちゃいけないけど、山登りの後にソフトクリームをなめるのは最高です。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've hopefully seen how 登る means "to climb." So, if you're <kanji>climb</kanji>ing a <kanji>mountain</kanji> what is that? It's <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.

In case you're wondering what the difference is between this and 登山, they are essentially the same. The main difference is that 山登り is a little less formal, and is generally used as a standalone word, whereas 登山 can be used in compound words like 登山家 (mountaineer).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from combining 山 and 登る together to form one word, 山登り. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.

examples.en: I don't know any of the recent buzzwords.
examples.ja: 最近の流行語は全然分かりません。

examples.en: A lot of new catchphrases are born every year, huh?
examples.ja: 毎年ほんとに色んな流行語が生まれるよね。

examples.en: Which popular phrase do you think will be chosen for this year's buzzword of the year?
examples.ja: どの流行語が、今年の流行語大賞に選ばれると思う？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 流行 means "trend", so "trend" <kanji>language</kanji> means a <vocabulary>popular phrase</vocabulary>. Yolo! It could also be a <vocabulary>catchphrase</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>popular word</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>buzzword</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, is the term "ryūkōka" a bit outdated? It sounds more like something grandparents would say.
examples.ja: え、「流行歌」って言葉、ちょっと古くない？おじいちゃんとかおばあちゃんっぽい。

examples.en: I don't know trendy songs these days at all.
examples.ja: ワシは今時の流行歌は全然分からんぞ。

examples.en: I heard this is a remake of a popular song from the 1950s.
examples.ja: これって50年代の流行歌のリメイクなんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 流行 refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" <kanji>song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>popular song</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: All of the dishes at this restaurant are delicious without exception.
examples.ja: このレストランの料理は例外なくどれもおいしいです。

examples.en: I think that case is an exception to the exceptions.
examples.ja: そのケースは例外中の例外だと思いますよ。

examples.en: I've heard that if the president is in a good mood, sometimes he'll make exceptions and say it's okay.
examples.ja: 社長の気分が良ければ、例外的にOKをもらえることもあるそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>outside</kanji> the <kanji>example</kanji> doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is just one example.
examples.ja: これはほんの一例にすぎません。

examples.en: The image is just an example.
examples.ja: 画像は一例です。

examples.en: This episode is just one example.
examples.ja: こちらのエピソードはあくまで一例です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>instance</vocabulary> of what you're describing. Just one <vocabulary>example</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: For example, let's say there was a person who used to be very popular but isn't at all anymore.
examples.ja: 例えば、昔はすごく人気があったけど、今は落ちぶれてしまった人がいたとしましょう。

examples.en: For example, if you encounter a coyote in the woods, what would you do?
examples.ja: 例えば、林でコヨーテに出くわした時、あなたならどうしますか？

examples.en: No, no, I'm just telling a what-if story, just a what-if story!
examples.ja: いやいや、例えばの話だよ、例えばの！

meaning_mnemonic: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's <vocabulary>for example</vocabulary>. It can also sometimes mean <vocabulary>supposing that</vocabulary> when talking about hypothetical scenarios. So, supposing that I start a sentence with this, I can be all like "例えば, I am using 例えば in a sentence."
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "<vocabulary>for examples</vocabulary>" like this, you were <reading>taught</reading> (たと) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

examples.en: Isn't this example sentence a bit odd?
examples.ja: この例文、ちょっとおかしくない？

examples.en: Please let us know which WaniKani example sentence is your favorite.
examples.ja: ワニカニの例文の中で一番好きな文章を教えてください。

examples.en: Oh, the example sentence has been updated.
examples.ja: あれ、例文が新しくなってる。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Example</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an <vocabulary>example sentence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Would you like to become a member of the WaniKani Association?
examples.ja: ワニカニ協会の会員になりませんか？

examples.en: I have to attend an organization meeting tomorrow, so please wake me up at six.
examples.ja: 明日は協会の集まりがあるので、六時に起こしてください。

examples.en: I work as an event manager for this association.
examples.ja: 僕はこの協会で、イベントマネージャーをしています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>cooperation</kanji>, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form <vocabulary>association</vocabulary>s. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Thank you all for your cooperation!
examples.ja: 皆様、ご協力ありがとうございます！

examples.en: Takuya helped out.
examples.ja: タクヤが協力してくれたんだ。

examples.en: Would you pretend to cooperate with us?
examples.ja: 私たちに協力するふりをしてくれませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Cooperation</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your level of <vocabulary>cooperation</vocabulary>. It's how much <vocabulary>collaboration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary> you provide.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh man, this is tough. Even if they say that, there are things that are just impossible.
examples.ja: いやー、参るな。そんなこと言われても、ムリなものはムリだからな。

examples.en: Every New Year's, my family visits the shrine together.
examples.ja: お正月には毎年家族で神社に参ります。

examples.en: Let's go!
examples.ja: いざ、参らん！

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>participate</kanji>, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it's a little more complex than that. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary> in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything. By extension, this is also a humble way to say <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>, often used if you're visiting something sacred like a shrine or a tomb. 

Historically, this word arose as a humble way to indicate visiting a person of higher social status. In a weird twist, this word has come to also mean <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be at a loss</vocabulary>. Think of it as what can happen when you're trying to participate while in an inferior position to someone or something.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> to participate! "It's <reading>my</reading> (まい) lucky day!" you exclaim.

examples.en: That runner went from tenth place to first place in the final lap.
examples.ja: あのランナーは、最後の一周で十位から一位になった。

examples.en: Koichi can run one lap of the track in three to four minutes.
examples.ja: コウイチはグラウンド一周を三分台で走ります。

examples.en: Next year, my family is going on a trip around the world.
examples.ja: 来年は家族で世界一周旅行に出かけるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>circumference</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time around</vocabulary>, or in racetrack sports, <vocabulary>one lap</vocabulary>. How many times will you go around the moon? Just 一周?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the いち becomes いっ as it often does when being used in a counter (一階, 一回, etc.).

examples.en: That lady always has yakuza-type guys hanging around her.
examples.ja: あの女性の周囲にはいつもヤクザ風の男がいる。

examples.en: Wary of the prying eyes of those around him, Koichi entered the black building.
examples.ja: コウイチは周囲の目を気にしながら黒いビルに入っていきました。

examples.en: Maybe you should consider the people around you a little more?
examples.ja: 周囲の人のこと、もうちょっと考えた方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: This is a small island with a circumference of six km.
examples.ja: この島は、周囲6キロの小さな島です。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>circumference</kanji> that <kanji>surround</kanji>s you is your <vocabulary>surroundings</vocabulary>.

周囲 commonly refers to your surroundings, whether it's the physical environment around you or your social circles. It can also refer to the <vocabulary>perimeter</vocabulary> of something, like the <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> of a lake or an object, though this usage is more technical and less common in everyday conversation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We're busy preparing for the anniversary event.

examples.en: Tomorrow marks the 15th anniversary since we started dating.

meaning_mnemonic:
When you wrap around the entire <kanji> circumference</kanji> of the <kanji>year</kanji> you've come back around to the start of it. This is the <vocabulary>anniversary</vocabulary>.

This word is commonly used with numbers, like 10周年 (10th anniversary), or combined with other words, like 周年事業 (anniversary project).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's fun to gather around the fire like this with everyone, isn't it?

examples.en: Japan is a country surrounded by the sea.

examples.en: Encircle the hiragana character "<ja>め</ja>" with a circle and encircle the character "<ja>ぬ</ja>" with a square.
examples.ja: ひらがなの「め」の字を丸で囲んで、「ぬ」の字を四角で囲んでください。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surround</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to surround</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enclose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

People <vocabulary>surround</vocabulary> you. They circle around you, calling you a chicken. "<reading>Cacko</reading>! (かこ) Cacko! Cacko!" Wait, this isn't the sound a chicken makes, right? You laugh at them, thinking their way of making a chicken noise is weird. Go ahead and join in with them and say "Cacko" with them as well.

examples.en: This café has a nice atmosphere, doesn't it?

examples.en: What's the atmosphere like in the office?

examples.en: The atmosphere in that meeting earlier was pretty intense, wasn't it?

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>surround</kanji>ing <kanji>energy</kanji> in the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> is what makes up the <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Note: You'll sometimes hear people say ふいんき, but if you wrote that on a test you'd be marked wrong, so we're sticking with the more standard ふんいき reading. If you need help remembering it, just look a little closer at the kanji — you'll know 雰 is ふん because it gets its reading from the little 分 inside it!

examples.en: This meat is a little tough.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>hard</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>tough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need something really <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary> to put in your <reading>cata</reading>pult(かた). Look around you for something hard and imagine putting it in your catapult!

examples.en: He is really stubborn.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hard</kanji> <kanji>stubborn</kanji> person is very <vocabulary>stubborn</vocabulary> no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Basically, all of our employees are good people.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> of your <kanji>foundation</kanji> is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the 基本 portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary> you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Japan has four seasons.

examples.en: In our restaurant, we aim to make customers feel the four seasons through our dishes.
examples.ja: うちのレストランでは、料理を通じてお客様に四季が感じていただきたいなと思っています。

examples.en: Here, you can enjoy beautiful seasonal flowers all year round.
examples.ja: ここでは美しい四季の花々が一年中楽しめます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>season</kanji>s are <vocabulary>the four seasons</vocabulary>. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 四 is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of し meaning "death" (like 死), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>nature</kanji> is just <vocabulary>human nature</vocabulary>! Everyone has their own human <vocabulary>instinct</vocabulary>s.

You only catch these sicknesses this way, meaning they're <vocabulary>sexually transmitted disease</vocabulary>s (save yourself some typing and just answer with <vocabulary>STD</vocabulary>).

examples.en: I'm about to fold the gyoza wrappers now.
examples.ja: 今からギョウザの皮を折るところです。

examples.en: I almost broke the bone in my foot.

examples.en: When I was folding the paper I got a paper cut.

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fold</kanji> or <kanji>break</kanji>, so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to fold something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <vocabulary>fold</vocabulary> your <reading>o</reading>bi (お) really carefully and put it away with the rest of your kimono.

examples.en: Are you going to throw away my valuable advice?
examples.ja: 俺の折角のアドバイスをムダにするつもりなのか？

examples.en: It's a shame that the shop isn't open despite coming all this way. But since we're here anyway, shall we try going to another nearby shop?
examples.ja: 折角来たのに、お店やってなくて残念だったね。でも折角だし、近くの他のお店に行ってみようか。

examples.en: She didn't like the jewelry I went through so much trouble to get.
examples.ja: 折角苦労して手に入れた宝石を、彼女は気に入ってくれなかった。

examples.en: Hmm. It's a rare opportunity to get a makeover, so I think I'll have my hair cut about thirty centimeters at the back.
examples.ja: うーん。折角イメチェンするいい機会だし、後ろ髪を三十センチくらい切ってもらおうかな。

meaning_mnemonic:
When there's nothing but <kanji>fold</kanji>s and <kanji>angle</kanji>s, you have quite a mess. This word means <vocabulary>with trouble</vocabulary> because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice, flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded.

折角 is one of those tricky Japanese words that doesn’t have one neat translation in English. The nuance is that something has come about with trouble, either through someone’s efforts, or a stroke of luck. It often implies regret, and is used in situations where you want to express that <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> opportunities, advice, or hard work were in vain for some reason. It’s also used to underline a <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary> chance that shouldn’t be missed.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the せつ changing to せっ, though. Another thing you have to go through <vocabulary>with trouble</vocabulary>, I'm afraid.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>bone</kanji> <kanji>break</kanji>s, you end up with, well, a <vocabulary>broken bone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fracture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because こつ is shortened to こっ here.

examples.en: Disappointment comes when things don't go as expected, precisely because you had expectations. If you don't expect anything from the beginning, you won't be disappointed either.
examples.ja: 期待するからこそ、期待通りにいかない時に失望しちゃうんだよ。最初から期待しなければ失望もしないさ。

meaning_mnemonic: There is <kanji>fault</kanji> in your <kanji>hope</kanji>. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive <vocabulary>disappointment</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.

examples.en: What are your desires?

examples.en: If it's your wish, I'll do anything for you.
examples.ja: 君の望みなら、僕は何でもしてあげるよ。

examples.en: Honestly, in life, things rarely go exactly as planned.
examples.ja: 正直、人生、望み通りに行くことの方が少ないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hope</kanji> is really a <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary> that you have inside of you (though it can still be a <vocabulary>hope</vocabulary> too).
reading_mnemonic: What's your one big <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>? It's to have a different <reading>nose</reading> (のぞ). Alternatively, you could think "<reading>nose on me</reading>" for のぞみ.

examples.en: I hope for nothing to happen.
examples.ja: 何事もないことを望むよ。

examples.en: You'll wear yourself out if you expect too much.
examples.ja: あまり多くを望むと、自分がしんどくなるよ。

examples.en: What kind of life do you wish for, Midori-san?
examples.ja: ミドリさんは、どんな生活を望んでいるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>hope</kanji> and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means <vocabulary>to wish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to desire</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger <reading>nose</reading> (のぞ). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

examples.en: Everyone has desires. There's no one without desires.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hope</kanji> you <kanji>request</kanji> is your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>.

Technically speaking, 木材 is used more for lumber or wood that hasn't been processed yet — less like planks, more like freshly cut lumber still lying on the forest floor. But it's not a hard rule or anything, so don't worry too much about the nuances.

reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. 松葉 is commonly used in compounds, such as 松葉ガニ (snow crab) or 松葉づえ (crutches).

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>status</kanji> refers to what kind of person you are deep-down. In other words, it's your <vocabulary>character</vocabulary>. Are you a person of character? Do you have a strong moral character?!

人格 is about the kind of person you are at your core. It's not about surface-level traits like being shy, cheerful, or forgetful, but about the deeper qualities that define you as a human being. In philosophical or scientific contexts, it can also refer to a person's <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary> as a technical concept, including intelligence and behavioral patterns.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The <vocabulary>remainder</vocabulary> of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret <reading>knock</reading> (のこ), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: <vocabulary>to remain behind</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide <vocabulary>to remain behind</vocabulary>. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone <reading>knock</reading>s (のこ) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an <vocabulary>-al</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>-like</vocabulary> to the end of it—or when something is <vocabulary>typical of</vocabulary> something else. For example, add it onto 日本 (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like", or "typically Japanese". It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>target</kanji>ed as <vocabulary>Japanese</vocabulary> are more than just Japanese, they are <vocabulary>very Japanese</vocabulary>. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 日本 as well.

Just imagine telling someone your 目的, only to have them laugh in your face and begin <reading>mock</reading>ing もく you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>promise</kanji>, but the meaning of this word is <vocabulary>about</vocabulary>, which is a little different. Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's <vocabulary>approximately</vocabulary> the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is actually the same one that you learned with the kanji, so no need to memorize anything new!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Take a look at your own <vocabulary>bone</vocabulary>s. They have been upgraded with special technology, allowing you to <reading>hone</reading> (ほね) in on targets, then shoot your bones at them. meaning_mnemonic: Hey. <kanji>Drop</kanji> yourself down and <kanji>arrive</kanji> back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things <vocabulary>to calm down</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 落ちる and 着く. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just 落ち着く and everything will be okay.

examples.en: I think this will take some time to digest.

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 消化 is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is <vocabulary>to digest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know 消化 you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

examples.en: This will erase with an eraser.
examples.ja: これ、消しゴムで消えるよ。

examples.en: Digital tattoos don't disappear for a lifetime, you know.

examples.en: Oh no, all the data is gone!
examples.ja: やばい、データが全部消えちゃった！

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 消す is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary> on its own. How can you differentiate this from 消す? Well, える allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin <reading>air</reading> (える). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from 消す, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a <reading>key</reading> (き) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical <reading>key</reading>.

examples.en: This picture is really creepy.

examples.en: I feel sick from eating too much.

meaning_mnemonic: The 気持ち (feeling) is <kanji>bad</kanji>. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a <vocabulary>bad feeling</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>feeling terrible</vocabulary>, in fact.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words 気持ち and 悪い. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?

examples.en: The water flowing in the nearby river was very clean.

examples.en: There, time flowed slowly.

examples.en: I was surprised when my favorite heavy metal song started playing from her speakers.

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to stream</vocabulary> (though it's also <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from 流す because with 流す you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you <reading>sue</reading> (す) the toilet maker. With 流れる you find a <reading>rare</reading> (れる) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 流す. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

examples.en: It's impossible for me to move this piano by myself.
