examples.ja: ちょっと車を動かしてくる！

examples.en: I move my body around here and there while doing desk work.
examples.ja: デスクワークをしながら、ちょこちょこ体を動かしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 動く hopefully, and know it means <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go <vocabulary>to move something</vocabulary> the thing you're moving starts to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす) you out because it's angry.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this can come from 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

examples.en: Do you want to wear earrings like these?
examples.ja: こういうイヤリング、着ける？

examples.en: I'm not really fond of wearing accessories.
examples.ja: 私、アクセサリーを着けるの、あんまり好きじゃないんです。

examples.en: How did you learn speed reading?
examples.ja: どうやって速読を身に着けたんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: 着る (to wear), 着く (to arrive), and now 着ける (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to 着る, right? In this case, this word is like 付ける, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 着く's reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with 付ける, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc.

examples.en: You must study everyday.
examples.ja: ちゃんと毎日勉強するんだよ。

examples.en: I like to study but I don't like to read.
examples.ja: 勉強することは好きなんですが、本を読むことはキライなんです。

examples.en: School is where you go to study.
examples.ja: 学校は勉強しに行くところですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 勉強 (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is <vocabulary>to study</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 勉強. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

examples.en: When are you planning to travel?
examples.ja: いつ旅行する予定なんですか？

examples.en: Ah, I want to travel.
examples.ja: あー、旅行したいな。

examples.en: I went there when I traveled to Hokkaido for the first time.
examples.ja: 初めて北海道旅行した時に、そこに行った。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's <vocabulary>to travel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take a trip</vocabulary>. These are fun to do. You should do them!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 旅行, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

examples.en: Don't wake him up for anything.
examples.ja: ゼッタイ起こすなよ。

examples.en: Can you wake me up tomorrow morning?
examples.ja: 明日の朝、起こしてくれない？

examples.en: That person caused a problem at work and got fired.
examples.ja: その人、仕事で問題を起こして、首になったんだよ。

examples.en: You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!
examples.ja: ビエットが100%正しいよ。今すぐコウイチ起こすべきだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to wake someone up</vocabulary>. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and <reading>sue</reading> (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. I guess if you wake someone up and they're not a morning person, you could cause something... like trouble.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 起きる, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

examples.en: Most of the visitors that come to this ski resort are foreign tourists.
examples.ja: このスキー場に来るのは、ほとんど外国人旅行者です。

examples.en: Universal Studios Japan is crowded even on weekdays because there are many foreign tourists.
examples.ja: ユニバは海外旅行者が多いから、平日でも空いてないんだよ。

examples.en: In many countries, restaurants aimed at tourists tend to be on the expensive side.
examples.ja: どこの国でも旅行者向けの飲食店は高めなことが多いですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is <kanji>someone</kanji> who goes on trips? That is a <vocabulary>tourist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>traveler</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of 旅行 already.

examples.en: I'm not fond of that person because they're always badmouthing others.
examples.ja: あの人、人の悪口ばっかり言うから苦手なんだよね。

examples.en: It's not considered speaking ill of someone, is it?
examples.ja: それって、悪口じゃなくない？

examples.en: I overheard everyone talking behind my back.
examples.ja: みんなが私の悪口を言っているのを聞いちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> produces nothing but <vocabulary>bad-mouthing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trash-talk</vocabulary>.

悪口 often targets someone's character, appearance, or abilities, with the intention of hurting them or damaging their reputation, sometimes to their face, but often behind their back. It gives rise to unfavorable information that can spread through gossip.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words 悪い and 口 to learn the reading of this word.

Okay, I lied. You should actually do わるぐち instead. わるくち is possible, but the rendaku version is way more common. Sorry to say such bad things before.

examples.en: What do you think is necessary for effective communication?
examples.ja: 良好なコミュニケーションをとるために必要なこととは何だと思いますか？

examples.en: To maintain good condition, daily care is essential.
examples.ja: コンディションを良好に保つには、日々のお手入れが欠かせません。

examples.en: After the surgery, everything was fine for a while, but the illness returned a year later.
examples.ja: 術後はしばらく良好でしたが、一年後に病気が再発したんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>good</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>favorable</vocabulary> thing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: I think it will take quite some time to organize all this data.
examples.ja: このデータを全て整理するには、かなり時間がかかると思います。

examples.en: Can I take a moment to organize your story?
examples.ja: ちょっと一回、話を整理させてもらっていいかな？

examples.en: Tell that employee to tidy up their desk!
examples.ja: あの社員に、デスクを整理するよう言っておいて！

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something with <kanji>reason</kanji> you're arranging it. That's why this is <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Huh, is this fully automatic?
examples.ja: え、これ全自動なんですか？

examples.en: I've set up all the data on my smartphone to automatically upload to the cloud.
examples.ja: スマホでのデータは、全て自動でクラウドにアップロードするようにセッティングしています。

examples.en: I didn't even realize it was an automatic door.
examples.ja: 自動ドアだって知らなかったんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that can <kanji>move</kanji> by its <kanji>self</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>automatic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In Japan, March is graduation season.
examples.ja: 日本では三月が卒業のシーズンです。

examples.en: The WaniKaniko-chan of the idol group TFG48 has announced her graduation.
examples.ja: アイドルグループTFG48のワニカニ子ちゃんが卒業を発表しました。

examples.en: Even after graduation, even after becoming adults, we'll always be best friends, right?
examples.ja: 卒業しても、大人になっても、私たち、ずっと親友だよね？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>business</kanji> of you <kanji>graduating</kanji> is your <vocabulary>graduation</vocabulary>. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We still have hope.
examples.ja: まだ希望はある。

examples.en: Now all hope is lost.
examples.ja: これで、希望は全て失われました。

examples.en: Do you have a seating preference?
examples.ja: お座席のご希望はございますか？

meaning_mnemonic: Both your <kanji>hope</kanji>s and <kanji>wish</kanji>es are held within this vocab word. So, what is the meaning of this word? It is both <vocabulary>hope</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>. Either will work.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't want to give in.
examples.ja: 妥協したくないの。

examples.en: I was struggling a bit mentally because I couldn't compromise well.
examples.ja: うまく妥協することができなくて、ちょっとメンタルやられちゃってたんだよね。

examples.en: It's not good to compromise on your work.
examples.ja: 仕事を妥協するのはよくないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>cooperation</kanji> nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a <vocabulary>compromise</vocabulary>. (Whether you like it or not.)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I feel sick due to indigestion.
examples.ja: 消化不良で気持ち悪い。

examples.en: I consulted with the teacher, but I still can't understand it well, so I'm feeling really frustrated for not digesting it well.
examples.ja: 先生に相談したんだけど、まだよく分からなくて消化不良ですごくモヤモヤしてるんだよね。

examples.en: Isn't it just indigestion? I mean, you did eat a lot of heavy stuff that's hard to digest.
examples.ja: ただの消化不良じゃないですか？ほら、消化に悪い物たくさん食べてたし。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 消化 by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji>. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? <vocabulary>Indigestion</vocabulary>. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 消化 and 不良 will help as well.

examples.en: I hope that doesn't happen.
examples.ja: そうならないことを期待するよ。

examples.en: Don't expect too much from me.
examples.ja: あまり期待しないでくださいね。

examples.en: I'm anticipating Valentine’s chocolate from girls other than my mother this year.
examples.ja: 今年は母親以外の女子からのバレンタインのチョコレートを期待しています。

meaning_mnemonic: Hopefully you know the word 期待 by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it <vocabulary>to expect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 期待, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

examples.en: A new conveyor belt sushi shop opened up.
examples.ja: 新しく回転ずしのお店がオープンした。

examples.en: If I go to Japan, I'd like to visit a conveyor belt sushi restaurant.
examples.ja: 日本に行ったら、回転ずしに行って見たいです。

examples.en: I started working part-time at a rotating sushi restaurant.
examples.ja: 回転ずし屋でバイトを始めました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 回転 is "rotation" and you probably know what すし is (gets rendaku'd in this word to ずし). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's <vocabulary>rotating sushi</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>conveyor belt sushi</vocabulary>. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 回転, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.

examples.en: Oh, this chair is a swivel chair.
examples.ja: あ、このイス、回転するイスなんだ。

examples.en: That pitcher is good at spinning the ball.
examples.ja: あのピッチャーはボールを回転させるのが上手い。

examples.en: I gave it my all and answered the quiz questions while my head was spinning.
examples.ja: 頭をフル回転させて、がんばってクイズに答えました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 回転 means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 回転 of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

examples.en: If you don't mind, why don't we play another game together?
examples.ja: 良かったらもう一試合しませんか？

examples.en: How was the soccer game?
examples.ja: サッカーの試合はどうでしたか？

examples.en: "That baseball game was really terrible." "Yeah, tell me about it."
examples.ja: 「あの野球の試合は本当にひどかったね。」「本当にそうだね。」

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>attempt</kanji> to <kanji>join</kanji> together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is <vocabulary>game</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>match</vocabulary>. Did you watch the 試合 today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi し for 試 and the kun'yomi あい for 合, which you learned with 場合. So you should be able to put them together!

examples.en: It took me a while to understand Tofugu's American jokes.
examples.ja: トーフグのアメリカン・ジョークを理解するのに時間がかかりました。

examples.en: I strive to ensure that the lessons can be understood by everyone.
examples.ja: 皆さんに本当に理解してもらえるようなレッスンになるよう、心がけています。

examples.en: I understand that you love him, but I don't want him to kiss you.
examples.ja: お前がアイツのことを好きなのは理解するけど、あいつがお前にキスをするのはイヤだよ。

examples.en: In order to get along well, it is important to understand the other person's position and feelings.
examples.ja: 仲良くするためには、相手の立場や気持ちを理解することが大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: 理解 is "understanding," so the verb version would be...? How about <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to comprehend</vocabulary>? Well, do you?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.

examples.en: Store closed today.
examples.ja: 本日閉店。

examples.en: Oh, has that convenience store closed down?
examples.ja: え、あそこのコンビニ、閉店しちゃったの？

examples.en: Our store opens at 10 a.m. and closes at 8 p.m.
examples.ja: うちのお店は、午前10時開店で、午後8時閉店となります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is when a store's status is <vocabulary>store closed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>closed store</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is the open and close switch for the door.
examples.ja: これがとびらの開閉スイッチです。

examples.en: You use this button to open and close the train doors.
examples.ja: このボタンで電車のドアの開閉をするんです。

examples.en: Being able to open and close the garage door shutters with a remote while in the car has made things a lot easier.
examples.ja: 車に乗りながらリモコンでシャッターの開閉が出来るので、すごく楽になりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Open</kanji>ed and <kanji>closed</kanji> things are <vocabulary>opening and closing</vocabulary>.

開閉 is a relatively formal word to refer to the action of opening and closing physical objects such as doors, shutters, or valves. You often see it in instruction manuals or product descriptions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you feel like it, how about going to karaoke with us now?
examples.ja: よかったら、今から俺らとカラオケ行かない？

examples.en: We just got out of school.
examples.ja: 俺ら、今、ちょうど学校出たとこだよ。

examples.en: Oh, we're not sure we can do that.
examples.ja: え、俺ら、それはちょっとムリだわ。

examples.en: I’m sorry. It’s obviously way too early for us to be having this conversation, but I just wanted to tell you that I want to marry you.
examples.ja: ごめん。 俺らがこの会話をするのは明らかにすごく早すぎたよな。でも、ただ、俺はお前と結婚したいと思ってるってこと、言いたかったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.

examples.en: There's a well over there.
examples.ja: あそこに井戸があるよ。

examples.en: You must not go into the well.
examples.ja: 井戸に入ってはいけないよ。

examples.en: Wait, didn't you just hear a voice coming from the well?
examples.ja: え、今、井戸から声がしなかった？

examples.en: The water from this well is not drinking water.
examples.ja: この井戸の水は飲み水ではありません。

examples.en: When I drank cold water from the well, I got brain freeze like when I ate cold ice cream.
examples.ja: よくひえた井戸水を飲むと、つめたいアイスクリームを食べた時のように頭がキーンといたみました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>well</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
reading_mnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for both of these kanji as their primary readings already, just watch out for 戸 getting rendaku'd so it becomes ど instead of と.

examples.en: He's good at matching the pace of others, isn't he?
examples.ja: 彼は相手のペースに合わせるのが上手いよね。

examples.en: I don't have a jacket that goes with this sweater.
examples.ja: このセーターに合わせる上着がない。

examples.en: You don't need to force yourself to fit in with others.
examples.ja: ムリして人に合わせる必要はないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for 合 is <kanji>join</kanji>, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is <vocabulary>to join together</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>to unify</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 合う, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

meanings: Thank You For Your Hard Work

examples.en: Good job! You worked hard.
examples.ja: お疲れ様！よくがんばったね。

examples.en: Thank you for your hard work, chief. I'll be taking my leave now.
examples.ja: お疲れ様でした、所長。お先に失礼します。

examples.en: Thank you for your hard work, Mr. Mayor. Do you have a moment right now?
examples.ja: 市長さん、お疲れ様です。今、ちょっとお時間よろしいですか？

examples.en: When my wife puts my jacket on the hanger she always says, "Thank you for working hard again today."
examples.ja: 私の妻は私の背広をハンガーに掛ける時に、「今日も一日お仕事お疲れ様でした」といつも言ってくれるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned). You say this to people when they've done good work — at the end of a workday or after a hard practice, for example. I guess the idea is that if they're tired, they've done some good work. Tell your coworkers お疲れ様でした when they leave for the day, or just use お疲れ in more casual situations with friends!
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 疲れ and 様, combined together into one word.

examples.en: In the gender section, I circled female!
examples.ja: 性のところ、女性に丸しておいたよ！

examples.en: This book is for sex education.
examples.ja: この本は、性教育のための本です。

examples.en: The physical differences between sexes are created by the action of sex hormones.
examples.ja: 体の性差は、性ホルモンの働きによって作り上げられているのです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

性 is a somewhat formal word to talk about <vocabulary>gender</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sex</vocabulary>, including sexual desire or activity. It's also a common suffix to describe the <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> of something. 安全性 refers to how safe something is by nature, for example, and ウィルス性 describes something virus-caused, like viral pneumonia.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Watch your opponent's movements closely!
examples.ja: 相手の動きをよく見て！

examples.en: This week, the market didn't show much movement.
examples.ja: 今週のマーケットは、あまり動きがありませんでした。

examples.en: That person’s movements are a little unnatural.
examples.ja: あの人、何だか動きが不自然ですね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>move</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is the same reading you learned from the word 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

examples.en: I'm collecting coins with serrated edges.
examples.ja: 周りがギザギザになっているコインを集めています。

examples.en: If there's something you love, you should stick with it regardless of what the other people say.
examples.ja: 大好きな事があるなら、周りが何と言おうと、それをやりつづけるべきだよ。

examples.en: I'm always worried about what other people are thinking about me.
examples.ja: いつも周りの目が気になるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>circumference</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You really want to measure the <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "<reading>Mah Wa</reading>lnuts! (まわ)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> to measure.

examples.en: Could you tell me the depth of this pool?
examples.ja: このプールの深さを教えて下さい。

examples.en: I was surprised by how deep it was.
examples.ja: 意外と深さがあってびっくりしたよ。

examples.en: I climbed down a ladder to a depth of 100 meters.
examples.ja: 百メートルの深さまでハシゴで下りました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>deep</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>depth</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 深い so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: My menstrual cycle is usually about twenty-eight days.
examples.ja: 私の生理周期はいつも大体２８日です。

examples.en: It seems that people's lives revolve through ups and downs in cycles of about 12 years.
examples.ja: 人の人生って、山あり谷ありが１２年周期で回っているらしいよ。

examples.en: Tohoku’s weather changes in short cycles.
examples.ja: 東北の天気は短い周期で変わる。

meaning_mnemonic: If you follow the <kanji>circumference</kanji> of a <kanji>period of time</kanji>, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full <vocabulary>cycle</vocabulary>. Events in history always repeat, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I had too much drink and I lost all sense of reason.
examples.ja: お酒を飲みすぎて、完全に理性を失ってしまっていました。

examples.en: If possible, I always want to be rational.
examples.ja: できるものなら、いつだって理性的でいたいと思っていますよ。

examples.en: I understood it was hopeless, but I couldn’t hold on to reason.
examples.ja: ダメだと分かっていたが、理性を保ってなかったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you have <kanji>reason</kanji> in your <kanji>nature</kanji>, you have <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intellect</vocabulary>.

This is "reason" as in logical thinking.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll be waiting for you in the waiting area.
examples.ja: 待合で待ってるね！

examples.en: I bumped into a friend from high school unexpectedly in the hospital waiting area.
examples.ja: 病院の待合で高校の時の友人にバッタリ会いました。

examples.en: Start squatting in the meeting place on my signal.
examples.ja: 合図をしたら、待合でスクワットを始めてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The place you <kanji>wait</kanji> to <kanji>join</kanji> other people is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>meeting place</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. 待ち → 待, 合い → 合 and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

examples.en: The voice was that of a child, but the words were those of an adult.
examples.ja: 声は子どもの声だったが、言葉つきはまるで大人だった。

examples.en: That worker's clear diction gives me a good impression.
examples.ja: あの社員は言葉つきがハキハキしていて好感がもてますね。

examples.en: I was surprised by how much my friend's language had changed in the time since I'd seen him.
examples.ja: しばらくぶりに会った友人の言葉つきがかなり変わっていてびっくりした。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 言葉 means "language?" Well, the way you "attach" (付き) language to things is your <vocabulary>diction</vocabulary>. Everyone has their own 言葉つき when they speak. How would you describe your 言葉つき?

言葉つき refers to the characteristics of <vocabulary>how one speaks</vocabulary>, including the words they choose, how they say them, and their overall speaking style.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My mother’s condition isn’t very good.
examples.ja: 母の具合があまりよくないんです。

examples.en: You don't look great at all.
examples.ja: なんかめっちゃ具合悪そうだね。

examples.en: I was a little under the weather yesterday.
examples.ja: ちょっと昨日から具合が良くなくて。

meaning_mnemonic: You have to find the right <kanji>tool</kanji> to <kanji>suit</kanji> your <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>state</vocabulary>. If you have a <vocabulary>health</vocabulary> condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 具 and the kun'yomi reading for 合. You've learned them both, so you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: That image appears to be deliberately created propaganda.
examples.ja: それは意図的に作り出されたプロパガンダの画像じゃないでしょうか。

examples.en: But don't you think it sounds a little like an intentionally made-up story?
examples.ja: でもそれちょっと、意図的な作り話っぽくない？

examples.en: Someone is deliberately controlling the information.
examples.ja: 誰かが意図的に情報をコントロールしているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You wouldn't put your <kanji>idea</kanji> in a <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>~like</kanji> format if it wasn't <vocabulary>intentional</vocabulary>. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 図 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You <vocabulary>intentional</vocabulary>ly stub your <reading>toe</reading> (と) all the time! If you hurt your toe <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary> you can get out of class and work! It's a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.

examples.en: It's really contemporary, isn't it?
examples.ja: とても近代的ですね。

examples.en: I like the contemporary design.
examples.ja: 近代的なデザインが気に入りました。

examples.en: That's a very modern way of thinking.
examples.ja: とても近代的な考え方ですね。

examples.en: I feel like the United States in the 1950s seems more modern than today.
examples.ja: 50年代の米国の方が今より近代的に見える気がする。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>period</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is very <vocabulary>contemporary</vocabulary>. But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't <vocabulary>modern</vocabulary> enough to touch your hands!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You shouldn't be mean.
examples.ja: 意地悪しちゃダメだよ。

examples.en: Don't say such mean things.
examples.ja: そんな意地悪なこと言わないでよ。

examples.en: Why are you so mean to my little sister?!
examples.ja: どうして妹に意地悪ばっかりするの！

meaning_mnemonic: A person whose <kanji>idea</kanji>s are <kanji>ground</kanji>ed in <kanji>evil</kanji> is a <vocabulary>malicious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> <vocabulary>jerk</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for 意 and 地, and the kun'yomi reading for 悪. You've learned them all already, but since 地 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Malicious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> <vocabulary>jerk</vocabulary>s get sent to <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) to sort them out. If anyone can sort out those malicious jerks, it’s Jesus!

examples.en: When I give the signal, please jump high.
examples.ja: 私が合図をしたら、大きくジャンプをしてください。

examples.en: Sam gave the signal by raising his thumb up.
examples.ja: サムは、親指を上げて合図を送った。

examples.en: That was the signal to start.
examples.ja: それがスタートの合図でした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>diagram</kanji> everyone <kanji>join</kanji>s together to see is a <vocabulary>signal</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 合 and the on'yomi reading for 図. You know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: When is your school's culture festival?
examples.ja: そっちの学校の文化祭っていつ？

examples.en: What time should we start the school festival rehearsal?
examples.ja: 文化祭の練習、何時にする？

examples.en: It seems like a famous person is going to come to our school's culture festival!
examples.ja: うちの文化祭に誰か有名人が来るらしいよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 文化 means "culture?" Well add <kanji>festival</kanji> to it and you end up with a <vocabulary>culture festival</vocabulary>! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called <vocabulary>school festival</vocabulary>s too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!

examples.en: I instinctively felt it was dangerous.
examples.ja: 本能的にヤバイって感じたんだよね。

examples.en: Cute! It tickles my maternal instincts.
examples.ja: かわいい！母性本能くすぐられる。

examples.en: That's a human instinct.
examples.ja: それは人間の本能です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>abilities</kanji> you <kanji>origin</kanji>ally start out with are <vocabulary>instinct</vocabulary>s. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tomorrow is sports day.
examples.ja: 明日は運動会です。

examples.en: I hope it doesn't rain on the day of the athletic meet.
examples.ja: 運動会の日、雨じゃないといいんですが。

examples.en: We practice every day in preparation for the sports festival.
examples.ja: 運動会に向けて、毎日練習しています。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 運動 means "exercise?" When you <kanji>meet</kanji> with a bunch of other people to exercise it's called <vocabulary>Sports Day</vocabulary>! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This carrot soup is delicious!
examples.ja: この人参スープ、おいしい！

examples.en: I gifted some carrot liqueur to the King who loves alcohol.
examples.ja: 酒好きの王様に、人参リキュールをプレゼントした。

examples.en: I can eat anything, but carrots are the only thing I can't handle.
examples.ja: 何でも食べれるけど、人参だけはムリです。

meaning_mnemonic: What do you use to get a <kanji>person</kanji> to <kanji>participate</kanji> in something? A <vocabulary>carrot</vocabulary>, of course. You've heard of "the carrot and the stick," right? So next time you want a person to participate, offer them a carrot.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 参 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're craving a <vocabulary>carrot</vocabulary>, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) the whole time!

examples.en: Until the shower water warms up, I'll wait here.
examples.ja: シャワーの水が温まるまで、ここで待ちます。

examples.en: With this heater, it takes so much time for the room to get warm.
examples.ja: このヒーターだと、部屋が温まるのにかなり時間がかかる。

examples.en: After running 1km, my body's getting warmed up.
examples.ja: 一キロ走って、体が温まってきた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 温 means <kanji>warm</kanji>. So the verb 温まる means <vocabulary>to warm up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get warm</vocabulary>. 

温まる is intransitive, so no direct object needed. Your cat warms up in the sunlight, for example. No direct object, right? A hint for this is that 温まる ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive!
reading_mnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as 温かい and 温める.

examples.en: This year's strawberries are expensive.
examples.ja: 今年の苺は高いです。

examples.en: That grocery store sells white strawberries.
examples.ja: あのスーパーに、白い苺が売ってるよ。

examples.en: I wonder if I should go for a strawberry sundae or a strawberry parfait.
examples.ja: 苺サンデーか苺パフェ、どっちにしようかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some strawberries to celebrate!

examples.en: I was raised by wolves.
examples.ja: 私は狼に育てられました。

examples.en: The baby wolves are doing well.
examples.ja: 狼の赤ちゃんたちは元気にしています。

examples.en: Around here, you can hear the howling of wolves at night.
examples.ja: この辺りは夜になると狼の鳴き声が聞こえます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I heard that another werewolf had appeared.
examples.ja: また狼男が出たらしい。

examples.en: Stop picking on the werewolf!
examples.ja: 狼男をいじめるのはやめろ！

examples.en: I was sick today so I took time off work and watched a movie about a werewolf.
examples.ja: 今日は病気で仕事を休んで狼男の映画を見た。

meaning_mnemonic: What’s another word for a <kanji>wolf</kanji> <kanji>man</kanji>? A <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary>, obviously.
reading_mnemonic: You learned the reading for 狼 in both the kanji and the vocabulary word. The reading for 男 comes from the vocabulary 男. Put them together and you get <reading>おおかみおとこ</reading>. Awoooo.

examples.en: I can read all the katakana letters from the sa row.
examples.ja: カタカナのサ行の文字は全て読めますよ。

examples.en: A sentence this long won’t fit in a single line.
examples.ja: こんなに長い文、一行には入らないよ。

examples.en: At important times like this, some adults have trouble reading between the lines.
examples.ja: こういう大切な時に行間を読めない大人っているよね。

examples.en: In Excel and other spreadsheets, horizontal lines are called "rows."
examples.ja: Excelやスプレッドシートでは、横方向のラインのことを「行」といいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You write the word <kanji>go</kanji> on a <vocabulary>line of text</vocabulary>. See the word "go" on that <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>, and think about where you're going.

This word can also be used for <vocabulary>row</vocabulary>s (horizontal lines in Excel and other spreadsheets).
reading_mnemonic:
There are two on'yomi readings for this kanji, but when it's used to mean lines of text, it's pronounced as ぎょう. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

You write out another <vocabulary>line of text</vocabulary> asking for some <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう). You write out that line of text slowly and carefully, in your very best handwriting. Turns out you were going to a gyoza restaurant and you want to make sure you impress the gyoza chef, so that they give you a ton of gyoza.

examples.en: Sheepskin is warm.
examples.ja: 羊の毛皮はあたたかい。

examples.en: This is a leopard fur coat.
examples.ja: これはヒョウの毛皮のコートです。

examples.en: I will never ever wear fur.
examples.ja: 私はゼッタイに毛皮を着ません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is pretty straightforward. You have <kanji>fur</kanji> and <kanji>skin</kanji>, making a word meaning <vocabulary>fur</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pelt</vocabulary>, like the kind that can be used to make garments.
reading_mnemonic: This is a special case because both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word. Luckily, you already know the kun'yomi reading from learning the vocabulary 毛 and 皮 previously. Just be careful with the rendaku on the second kanji, 皮.

examples.en: It's obvious that your mom really likes wine.
examples.ja: あなたのお母さんがワイン好きなのは明らかです。

examples.en: It turned out that he has some Irish heritage in his blood.
examples.ja: 彼にアイルランド人の血が入ってることが明らかになりました。

examples.en: Koichi is clearly acting strange today.
examples.ja: 今日のコウイチは明らかにおかしい。

meaning_mnemonic: When it's <kanji>bright</kanji> around, things become more <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>clear</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>evident</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this is a word that consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it uses kun'yomi. Unfortunately, 明 is a little tricky and has a few of those. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember this one:

It's <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary> that all you need is <reading>a key</reading> (あき) to open this door. It's like, blatantly <vocabulary>clear</vocabulary>. The lock is right there. You really just need a key. Did you forget it? Of course you did…

examples.en: Thank you for your great kindness in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本ではお世話になりました。

examples.en: You're truly a high-maintenance child!
examples.ja: あんたは本当に世話のかかる子だね！

examples.en: Yikes! Taking care of a baby is way tougher than I thought.
examples.ja: ヤバイ！赤子の世話、思ってたよりめっちゃキツイわ。

meaning_mnemonic: Older <kanji>generation</kanji>s mostly <kanji>talk</kanji> about one thing: <vocabulary>care</vocabulary>. Everybody wants to receive care once they're older, don't they?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 世 is せ here, and not せい!
